content.text: You know, if someone had told me back in 8th grade that “AI will become a normal word in your vocab,” I would’ve laughed. Proper laughed. Because before Covid, “AI” was this distant sci-fi thing from Marvel movies and clickbait thumbnails. But then Covid came… and suddenly half the world was online 24/7. Including me. Obviously.
The First Time I Opened It

At first I didn’t even understand what ChatGPT was. Like, AI that can "talk"? AI that can "think"? Bro even my friends don’t answer properly. I remember sitting in 9th grade, online classes on one tab, Google Forms exams on another, and then a new tab on the side that said ChatGPT. The name itself sounded like a Tony Stark side-project. I typed something stupid like "hey." It replied. Sometimes it was helpful. Sometimes completely off. It felt like an infant mind learning while you watched. Cute. A bit scary.

By 10th grade , still Covid, still classes online , ChatGPT wasn’t a toy anymore. It was normal. Like Google. Like video calls. Everyone started saying: “GPT se pooch le.” “GPT bata dega.” “GPT ko dekh ke likh lo.” Wild.
From Infant Mind to Supercomputer

It kept getting smarter. Monthly. Updates were like watching a toddler become a calculator that also tells jokes. At first basic answers. Then explanations. Then code. Then style. Then essays. Meanwhile I was eating biscuits and refreshing tabs. It stopped being 'a thing' and became a presence. Not scary. Not cozy. Just permanently there, like background noise in my room.
I keep thinking , did we grow up with AI or did AI grow up with us? Either way, it arrived quietly and we woke up inside it.
